Decisions, from "Do You Believe In Magic", a song by the Lovin' Spoonful
item.description: “Do You Believe in Magic” (Lovin’ Spoonful) Did you ever have to make up your mind? Pick up on one and leave the other one behind It’s not often easy, and not often kind Did you ever have to make up your mind? Did you ever have to finally decide? Say yes to one and let the other one ride There’s so many changes, and tears you must hide Did you ever have to finally decide?

item.title: Decisions, from "Sophie's Choice"" with Meryl Streep
item.description: “Sophie’s Choice” (directed by Alan J. Pakula) In a from the movie “Sophie’s Choice,” ) a Nazi officer at a concentration camp demands that a holocaust prisoner, played by Meryl Streep, decide which of the two young children at her side will live and which will be snatched away. The scene is excruciating. Everyone, especially parents, cringes – no, they cry inside at the pathological cruelty of this monstrous decision forced on a mother.

item.title: Alcohol -- Absinthe painting by Edgar Degas
item.description: At the focus spot of a well-known painting by Edgar Degas, “The Absinthe” [“L’Absinthe”], sits a full glass of absinthe. According to one summary, “Absinthe (also known as La Fée Verte or ‘the green fairy’) was a green colored, highly alcoholic spirit. Poured over ice and served with water and a cube of sugar to soften the bitter taste, it was [thought to be] highly addictive and known to cause hallucinations.

item.title: About This Project
item.description: Poems tell miniature stories, as do song lyrics, paintings and scenes in movies. The stories in each art form suggest a range of cultural memes. For example, a collection of one from each art form might make the careful viewer aware of a tangible feature such as a hat or a factory, or perhaps an abstraction such as suffering or hope. But this notion of stories in common across art forms extends more broadly.
